Training Time Minimization for Federated Edge Learning with Optimized Gradient Quantization and Bandwidth Allocation

Peixi¬†Liu ¬†Jiamo¬†Jiang ¬†Guangxu¬†Zhu ¬†Lei¬†Cheng ¬†Wei¬†Jiang ¬†Wu¬†Luo ¬†Ying¬†Du ¬†Zhiqin¬†Wang Peixi Liu is with State Key Laboratory of Advanced Optical Communication Systems and Networks, School of Electronics, Peking University, Beijing, China, and Shenzhen Research Institute of Big Data, Shenzhen, China (e-mail: liupeixi@pku.edu.cn).Jiamo Jiang, Ying Du and Zhiqin Wang are with China Academy of Information and Communications Technology (e-mail: jiangjiamo, duying1, zhiqin.wang@caict.ac.cn).Guangxu Zhu is with Shenzhen Research Institute of Big Data, Shenzhen, China (e-mail: gxzhu@sribd.cn).Lei Cheng is with College of Information Science and Electronic Engineering, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, China (e-mail: lei_cheng@zju.edu.cn)Wei Jiang and Wu Luo are with State Key Laboratory of Advanced Optical Communication Systems and Networks, School of Electronics, Peking University, Beijing, China (e-mail: jiangwei, luow@pku.edu.cn).
Abstract

Training a machine learning model with federated edge learning (FEEL) is typically time-consuming due to the constrained computation power of edge devices and limited wireless resources in edge networks. In this paper, the training time minimization problem is investigated in a quantized FEEL system, where the heterogeneous edge devices send quantized gradients to the edge server via orthogonal channels. In particular, a stochastic quantization scheme is adopted for compression of uploaded gradients, which can reduce the burden of per-round communication but may come at the cost of increasing number of communication rounds. The training time is modeled by taking into account the communication time, computation time and the number of communication rounds. Based on the proposed training time model, the intrinsic trade-off between the number of communication rounds and per-round latency is characterized. Specifically, we analyze the convergence behavior of the quantized FEEL in terms of the optimality gap. Further, a joint data-and-model-driven fitting method is proposed to obtain the exact optimality gap, based on which the closed-form expressions for the number of communication rounds and the total training time are obtained. Constrained by total bandwidth, the training time minimization problem is formulated as a joint quantization level and bandwidth allocation optimization problem. To this end, an algorithm based on alternating optimization is proposed, which alternatively solves the subproblem of quantization optimization via successive convex approximation and the subproblem of bandwidth allocation via bisection search. With different learning tasks and models, the validation of our analysis and the near-optimal performance of the proposed optimization algorithm are demonstrated by the experimental results.

Index Terms:
Federated edge learning, quantization optimization, bandwith allocation, training time minimization

I Introduction

The evolution of wireless networks from 1G to 5G-Advanced has witnessed a paradigm shift from connecting people targeting human-type communications towards connecting intelligence targeting machine-type communications to attain the vision of artificial intelligence of things (AIoT). This has driven the rapid development of an emerging area called edge intelligence, sitting at the intersection of the two disciplines, namely artificial intelligence (AI) and wireless communications [1, 2]. In edge intelligence, AI technologies are pushed towards the network edge so that the edge servers can quickly access real-time data generated by edge devices for fast training and real-time inference [3]. A promising framework for distributed edge learning, called federated edge learning (FEEL), has recently been pushed into the spotlight, which distributes the task of model training to edge devices and keeps the data locally at the edge devices so as to avoid data uploading and thus preserve user-privacy [4, 5, 6]. Specifically, a typical training process of FEEL involves multiple rounds of wireless communication between the edge server and devices. In a particular round, the edge server firstly broadcasts the global model under training to the edge devices for local stochastic gradient decent (SGD) execution using local data, and then the edge devices upload their local models/gradients to the edge server for aggregation and global model updating. After the convergence criterion is met, such as attaining a desired level of accuracy or reaching a pre-defined value of the loss, the entire training process will be completed, and then on-device models can be tweaked for the edge device‚Äôs personalization.

In edge networks, the computation resource of the edge devices are constrained, and the wireless resource of the network, e.g., frequency bandwidth, is also limited, so training a AI model by FEEL is usually a time-consuming and expensive task that can take anywhere from hours to weeks to complete [7]. Hence, training time111This is also called wall-clock time in some literature [8, 9]. In this work, we use ‚Äútotal training time‚Äù, ‚Äútraining time‚Äù, and ‚Äúwall-clock time‚Äù interchangeably. minimization of AI models is one of the critical concerns in FEEL. The whole training process of FEEL typically consists of multiple communication rounds, and each lasts for a period of time consisting of computation time and communication time, which we called per-round latency. To reduce the total training time, we should not only bring down the number of communication rounds, i.e., speed up the convergence rate of the learning algorithm, but also shorten the per-round latency. Communication-efficient transmission achieved through compression is usually included into the FEEL pipeline to alleviate the transmission burden of the edge devices, and thus reduce the per-round latency [10]. Two main lossy compression techniques, namely quantization and sparsification, as well as combination of them, have been considered in the literature [11, 12, 13, 14, 15, 16, 17, 18, 19]. Specifically, in the case of quantization, the gradient vector entries are transmitted after being quantized to finite bits, instead of the full floating-point values [14, 15, 16]; sparsification reduces the communication overhead by only sending significant entries of the gradient vector [17, 18, 19]. Although the compressed transmission can decrease the per-round latency, the lossy compression will degrade the convergence speed of FEEL as well, which leads to the increase in the number of communication rounds to achieve a certain accuracy on a given task [13]. As a result, the compression level balances the trade-off between the number of communication rounds and per-round latency in minimization of the total training time in FEEL. Besides, the edge devices in the edge network are usually heterogeneous such that some of edge devices with lower computation power become laggards in the synchronous model/gradient aggregation due to their longer computation time, which increases the per-round latency. It is necessary to consider the optimization of wireless resources over different edge devices to reduce the communication time of the lagging edge devices, and compensate the longer computation time [20, 21, 22]. With the goal of minimizing the total training time, we study the following question: How to balance the trade-off between the number of communication rounds and per-round latency via joint quantization level and bandwidth allocation optimization in the presence of device heterogeneity.

I-A Related work

Recently, extensive efforts have been made to minimize the total training time of FEEL by resource allocation or gradient/model compression, which mainly fall into three categories in terms of their objectives:

I-A1 Minimization of the number of communication rounds

This is equivalent to accelerating the convergence speed of FEEL algorithms. In [4], the authors minimized the global loss function by optimizing communication resource, e.g., power and bandwidth, and computation resource under given per-round latency constraint, and thus the convergence speed was maximized. The works in [23] and [24] considered quantization and bandwidth optimization to accelerate the algorithm convergence speed of FEEL with device sampling in the presence of outage probability. In [25], a stochastic gradient quantization was adopted to compress the local gradient, and the quantization levels of each devices were optimized to minimize the optimality gap under multiple access channel capacity constraints. These efforts have focused on speeding up the convergence of FEEL algorithms, i.e., reducing the number of communication rounds, without considering minimizing the total training time, which is a more practical and important issue in FEEL.

I-A2 Minimization of per-round latency

The work in [20] and [21] studied the trade-off between per-round latency and energy consumption by introducing a weight factor, and these two objectives tend to form a competitive interaction. In [5], the authors analyzed the per-round latency of different multiple access schemes in FEEL, i.e., the proposed broadband analog aggregation (BAA) and the traditional OFDMA, and proved that the proposed BAA can significantly reduce the per-round latency compared to the traditional OFDMA. The resource allocation in [20], [21], and [5] were considered over each single communication round; nevertheless, FEEL is a long-term process consisting of many communication rounds that together determine the total training time.

I-A3 Minimization of total training time

The work in [22] minimized the total training time by optimizing communication and computation resource allocation; however, no compression was considered in [22]. The authors in [7] minimized the training time for a fixed communication rounds by solving a joint learning, wireless resource allocation, and device selection problem. Some of other works didn‚Äôt minimize the training time directly, but they considered to minimize the loss function in a given training time. For example, the work in [9] studied the communication trade-off balanced by compression and local update steps in fixed training time, but the communication resource allocation was not taken into consideration. The authors in [26] adopted the idea of signSGD with majority vote [27] and optimized the power allocations and CPU frequencies under the trade-off between the number of communication rounds versus the outage probability per communication round for fixed training time.

Despite the above research efforts, these prior works have overlooked the inherent trade-off in minimizing the total training time of communication-efficient FEEL between the number of communication rounds and per-round latency, which is balanced by the quantization level at the edge devices. Moreover, the communication resource allocation among different edge devices and the compression setup for minimizing the total training time of communication-efficient FEEL should be jointly considered. This thus motivates the current work.

I-B Our contribution

This paper studies a FEEL system consisting of multiple edge devices with heterogeneous computational capabilities and one edge server for coordinating the learning process. We consider quantized FEEL where a stochastic quantization scheme is adopted for updated gradients compression, which can save per-round communication cost but may at a cost of increased number of communication rounds. Thus, we make a comprehensive analysis on the total training time by taking into account the communication time, computation time and the number of communication rounds, based on which the intrinsic trade-off between the number of communication rounds and per-round latency is characterized. Then, building on the analytical results, a joint quantization and bandwidth allocation optimization problem is formulated and solved. The main contributions are elaborated as follows.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Training time analysis in quantized FEEL: The challenge of analyzing the total training time mainly lies in estimating the required communication rounds for model convergence. To tackle the challenge, we analyze the convergence behavior of quantized FEEL in terms of the optimality gap and establish the expression of the minimum number of communication rounds that achieves a given optimality gap of the loss function. However, the derived results are generally too loose to be used for further optimization. In order to yield an accurate estimate on the required number of communication rounds, we propose a joint data-and-model-driven fitting method to further refine and tighten the derived result. Thanks to the refinement, an accurate estimate of the total training time can be attained and the trade-off between the number of communication rounds and per-round latency can be better characterized.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Training time minimization via joint optimization of quantization and bandwidth: Next, building on the derived analytical results, we formulate the total training time minimization problem by jointly optimizing the quantization level and bandwidth allocation, subject to a maximum bandwidth constraint in FEEL network. The problem is non-convex, and thus challenging to solve. To tackle the challenge, we adopt the alternating optimization technique to decompose the problem into two subproblems, and each optimizes one of the two control variables with the other fixed. For the sub-problem of bandwidth allocation with fixed quantization level, it can be solved by bisection search efficiently; for the sub-problem of quantization optimization with bandwidth allocation fixed, a algorithm based on successive convex approximation is proposed.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Performance evaluation: Finally, we conduct extensive simulations to evaluate the performance of task-oriented resource allocation for quantized FEEL by considering the logistic regression (convex loss function) on a synthetic dataset and a convolution neural network (non-convex loss function) on CIFAR-10 dataset. It is shown that the proposed joint data-and-model-driven fitting method can fit the curve of actual optimality gap well. In addition, it is shown that the optimal quantization level found by solving the formulated optimization problem matches well with the simulation result. The benefits of optimizing the bandwidth allocation in coping with the devices heterogeneity are also demonstrated.

I-C Organization and notations

Organization: The remainder of the paper is organized as follows. Section II introduces the system model, including the FEEL procedure, the quantization scheme, and the channel models. Section III analyzes the convergence of quantized FEEL,where a joint-data-and-model driven fitting approach is proposed to attain a tight approximation of the total training time. The optimization problem for minimizing the total training time is formulated and then solved in Section IV. Section V shows the experimental results using synthetic and real dataset, followed by conclusion in Section VI.

Note that we do not claim that this quantization scheme is optimal in terms of the communication efficiency. Rather, we adopt it as a simple and general scheme that facilitates the subsequent analysis of the trade-off between the number of communication rounds and per-round communication latency, controlled by the quantization level.

II-C Wireless transmission model

In the quantized FEEL system, each edge device connects to the edge server via a shared wireless medium. We assume that the spectrum is divided into distinct and non-overlapping flat fading channels with different bandwidth, so that the edge devices share the spectrum through frequency division multiple access to avoid interferences with each other. In general, modern neural network models are of high dimension with dùëëd in the order of 106‚àº109similar-tosuperscript106superscript10910^{6}\sim 10^{9}. Hence, it usually takes much longer than the coherence period to transmit a complete model. For example, a single LTE frame of 5 MHz bandwidth and 10 ms duration can carry only 6000 complex symbols [12]. To transmit a moderate neural network model with 106superscript10610^{6} parameters encoded by 32-bit floating-point values, it will approximately take 6 seconds, which is much longer than the frame length, i.e., 10 ms. Moreover, in some Internet of Things (IoT) networks, which are typically bandwidth and power limited [28], it takes more time to transmit a machine learning model. Hence, it is reasonable to model the wireless uplink channels as independent and identical distributed (i.i.d.) fast Rayleigh fading channel in the course of training, i.e., the channel coefficients remain constant over each coherence period and vary in an i.i.d. across different coherence periods, and the codeword or frame will span multiple coherence periods [29]. Specifically, the channel propagation coefficient between edge server and device kùëòk is generally modeled as hk=œïk‚Äãh¬Øksubscript‚Ñéùëòsubscriptitalic-œïùëòsubscript¬Ø‚Ñéùëòh_{k}=\sqrt{\phi_{k}}\overline{h}_{k}; here, œïksubscriptitalic-œïùëò\phi_{k} describes the large-scale propagation effects, including path loss and shadowing, and h¬Øksubscript¬Ø‚Ñéùëò\overline{h}_{k} denotes small-scale fading modeled as i.i.d. CSCG random variables with zero mean and unit variance, i.e., h¬Øk‚àºùíû‚Äãùí©‚Äã(0,1)similar-tosubscript¬Ø‚Ñéùëòùíûùí©01\overline{h}_{k}\sim\mathcal{CN}(0,1). The large-scale propagation coefficient œïksubscriptitalic-œïùëò\phi_{k} remains unchanged in a whole time frame, while the small-scale fading h¬Øksubscript¬Ø‚Ñéùëò\overline{h}_{k} varies from coherence block to another in a time frame. Moreover, we assume that the channel coefficients are only known at the edge server, which can be obtained by channel estimation at the server.

In this situation, the ergodic capacity can be assigned to the fast fading channel, which can be achieved in practice by interleaving technique [29]. The ergodic capacity of device kùëòk is given by

Rk=ùîºhk‚Äã[bk‚Äãlog2‚Å°(1+pk‚Äã|hk|2bk‚ÄãN0)],subscriptùëÖùëòsubscriptùîºsubscript‚Ñéùëòdelimited-[]subscriptùëèùëòsubscript21subscriptùëùùëòsuperscriptsubscript‚Ñéùëò2subscriptùëèùëòsubscriptùëÅ0R_{k}=\mathbb{E}_{h_{k}}\left[b_{k}\log_{2}\left(1+\frac{p_{k}|h_{k}|^{2}}{b_{k}N_{0}}\right)\right], (4)

where bksubscriptùëèùëòb_{k} denotes the frequency bandwidth allocated for device kùëòk with ‚àëk=1Kbk=B0superscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsubscriptùëèùëòsubscriptùêµ0\sum_{k=1}^{K}b_{k}=B_{0}; pksubscriptùëùùëòp_{k} denotes the transmit power at device kùëòk; N0subscriptùëÅ0N_{0} denotes noise power spectral density; the expectation is taken over the channel distribution.

III Training time analysis

The training time of each device for one communication round comprises computation time TkcompsuperscriptsubscriptùëáùëòcompT_{k}^{\text{comp}} and communication time TkcommsuperscriptsubscriptùëáùëòcommT_{k}^{\text{comm}}, as illustrated in Fig. 2. Since the server broadcasts the same global model to all the devices using the entire frequency band, the downlink delay due to global model broadcasting is ignorable compared with the uplink delay due to updates uploading from many devices to the server. Assume that the delay requirement for running one round training is TdsubscriptùëáùëëT_{d}, i.e., Tkcomp+Tkcomm‚â§TdsuperscriptsubscriptùëáùëòcompsuperscriptsubscriptùëáùëòcommsubscriptùëáùëëT_{k}^{\text{comp}}+T_{k}^{\text{comm}}\leq T_{d}. We define NœµsubscriptùëÅitalic-œµN_{\epsilon} as the minimum number of communication rounds when œµitalic-œµ\epsilon-optimality gap is achieved, i.e., F‚Äã(ùê∞(Nœµ))‚àíF‚Äã(ùê∞‚àó)‚â§œµùêπsuperscriptùê∞subscriptùëÅitalic-œµùêπsubscriptùê∞‚àóitalic-œµF(\mathbf{w}^{(N_{\epsilon})})-F(\mathbf{w}_{\ast})\leq\epsilon, where ùê∞‚àósubscriptùê∞‚àó\mathbf{w}_{\ast} denotes the optimal model as ùê∞‚àó=arg‚Å°minùê∞‚Å°F‚Äã(ùê∞)subscriptùê∞‚àósubscriptùê∞ùêπùê∞\mathbf{w}_{\ast}=\arg\min\limits_{\mathbf{w}}F(\mathbf{w}). The training process stops when œµitalic-œµ\epsilon-optimality gap is achieved. Then, the requirement of total training time over NœµsubscriptùëÅitalic-œµN_{\epsilon} rounds is given by

T=Nœµ‚ãÖTd.ùëá‚ãÖsubscriptùëÅitalic-œµsubscriptùëáùëëT=N_{\epsilon}\cdot T_{d}. (5)

In the following, we give the expression of per-round training time TdsubscriptùëáùëëT_{d}, and obtain the minimum number of communication rounds NœµsubscriptùëÅitalic-œµN_{\epsilon} by analyzing the convergence of FEEL, which paves the way for minimizing the total training time defined in (5) in next section.

III-A Computation time

Let ŒΩùúà\nu denote the number of processing cycles for one particular edge device to execute one batch of samples, and fksubscriptùëìùëòf_{k} denote the CPU frequency of device kùëòk. Accordingly, the computation time for running one-round SGD at device kùëòk is given by [30]

Tkcomp=ŒΩfk.superscriptsubscriptùëáùëòcompùúàsubscriptùëìùëòT_{k}^{\text{comp}}=\frac{\nu}{f_{k}}.

III-B Communication time

Let SùëÜS denote the number of bits for transmission after stochastic quantization. For quantizing any element gisubscriptùëîùëñg_{i} in gradient vector ùê†‚àà‚Ñùdùê†superscript‚Ñùùëë\mathbf{g}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} as noted from (2), we need to encode the vector norm ‚Äñùê†‚Äñnormùê†\|\mathbf{g}\|, the element-wise sign sgn‚Äã(gi)sgnsubscriptùëîùëñ\mathrm{sgn}(g_{i}), and the normalized quantization value Œæi‚Äã(ùê†,q)subscriptùúâùëñùê†ùëû\xi_{i}(\mathbf{g},q) into bits. Particularly, it takes one bit to encode each of the sgn‚Äã(gi)sgnsubscriptùëîùëñ\mathrm{sgn}(g_{i}). Assuming that Œæi‚Äã(ùê†,q)subscriptùúâùëñùê†ùëû\xi_{i}(\mathbf{g},q)‚Äôs have uniform distribution222In practice, Œæi‚Äã(ùê†,q)subscriptùúâùëñùê†ùëû\xi_{i}(\mathbf{g},q)‚Äôs can have non-uniform probability distribution. There exit more efficient coding methods coping with such non-uniform distribution as reported in [14], which are nevertheless much more complicated for analysis and optimization. In this work, we only consider the uniform distribution and leave those complicated ones for future work. with support {0,1/q,2/q,‚Ä¶,1\{0,1/q,2/q,\dots,1}, it takes at least log2‚Å°(1+q)subscript21ùëû\log_{2}(1+q) bits to encode each Œæi‚Äã(ùê†,q)subscriptùúâùëñùê†ùëû\xi_{i}(\mathbf{g},q) [31]. Since each vector containing dùëëd entries, it takes in total (1+log2‚Å°q)‚Äãd1subscript2ùëûùëë(1+\log_{2}q)d bits to encode these two parts. By contrast, the overhead in encoding the single scalar vector norm ‚Äñùê†‚Äñnormùê†\|\mathbf{g}\| is typically negligible for large models of size dùëëd [32]. To facilitate the subsequent analysis, for large dùëëd we approximate SùëÜS via

S=(1+log2‚Å°(q+1))‚Äãd.ùëÜ1subscript2ùëû1ùëëS=(1+\log_{2}(q+1))d. (6)

The communication delay in one round is

Tkcomm=SRk,superscriptsubscriptùëáùëòcommùëÜsubscriptùëÖùëòT_{k}^{\text{comm}}=\frac{S}{R_{k}}, (7)

where RksubscriptùëÖùëòR_{k} is the ergodic capacity defined in (4).

III-C Minimum number of communication rounds

In this subsection, we derive NœµsubscriptùëÅitalic-œµN_{\epsilon} by analyzing the convergence of quantized FEEL. To this end, we make the following assumptions on the local loss functions {Fk‚Äã(ùê∞)}subscriptùêπùëòùê∞\{F_{k}(\mathbf{w})\}.

Assumption 1 (Smoothness).

The local loss functions {Fk‚Äã(ùê∞)}subscriptùêπùëòùê∞\{F_{k}(\mathbf{w})\} are all LùêøL-smooth: for all ùê∞isubscriptùê∞ùëñ\mathbf{w}_{i} and ùê∞jsubscriptùê∞ùëó\mathbf{w}_{j}, Fk‚Äã(ùê∞i)‚â§Fk‚Äã(ùê∞j)+(ùê∞i‚àíùê∞j)T‚Äã‚àáFk‚Äã(ùê∞j)+L2‚Äã‚Äñùê∞i‚àíùê∞j‚Äñ2subscriptùêπùëòsubscriptùê∞ùëñsubscriptùêπùëòsubscriptùê∞ùëósuperscriptsubscriptùê∞ùëñsubscriptùê∞ùëóùëá‚àásubscriptùêπùëòsubscriptùê∞ùëóùêø2superscriptnormsubscriptùê∞ùëñsubscriptùê∞ùëó2F_{k}(\mathbf{w}_{i})\leq F_{k}(\mathbf{w}_{j})+\left(\mathbf{w}_{i}-\mathbf{w}_{j}\right)^{T}\nabla F_{k}(\mathbf{w}_{j})+\frac{L}{2}\left\|\mathbf{w}_{i}-\mathbf{w}_{j}\right\|^{2}, ‚àÄkfor-allùëò\forall k.

Assumption 2 (Strongly convexity).

The local loss functions {Fk‚Äã(ùê∞)}subscriptùêπùëòùê∞\{F_{k}(\mathbf{w})\} are all Œºùúá\mu-strongly convex: for all ùê∞isubscriptùê∞ùëñ\mathbf{w}_{i} and ùê∞jsubscriptùê∞ùëó\mathbf{w}_{j}, Fk‚Äã(ùê∞i)‚â•Fk‚Äã(ùê∞j)+(ùê∞i‚àíùê∞j)+(ùê∞i‚àíùê∞j)T‚Äã‚àáFk‚Äã(ùê∞j)+Œº2‚Äã‚Äñùê∞i‚àíùê∞j‚Äñ2subscriptùêπùëòsubscriptùê∞ùëñsubscriptùêπùëòsubscriptùê∞ùëósubscriptùê∞ùëñsubscriptùê∞ùëósuperscriptsubscriptùê∞ùëñsubscriptùê∞ùëóùëá‚àásubscriptùêπùëòsubscriptùê∞ùëóùúá2superscriptnormsubscriptùê∞ùëñsubscriptùê∞ùëó2F_{k}(\mathbf{w}_{i})\geq F_{k}(\mathbf{w}_{j})+\left(\mathbf{w}_{i}-\mathbf{w}_{j}\right)+\left(\mathbf{w}_{i}-\mathbf{w}_{j}\right)^{T}\nabla F_{k}(\mathbf{w}_{j})+\frac{\mu}{2}\left\|\mathbf{w}_{i}-\mathbf{w}_{j}\right\|^{2}, ‚àÄkfor-allùëò\forall k.

Assumption 3 (First and second moments of local gradients).

The mean and variance of stochastic gradients ùê†k(n)superscriptsubscriptùê†ùëòùëõ\mathbf{g}_{k}^{(n)} of local loss functions Fk‚Äã(ùê∞)subscriptùêπùëòùê∞F_{k}(\mathbf{w}), for all n‚àà[N]ùëõdelimited-[]ùëÅn\in[N] and ‚àÄkfor-allùëò\forall k, satisfy that

(Unbiased) ùîº‚Äã[ùê†k(n)]=‚àáFk‚Äã(ùê∞(n)),ùîºdelimited-[]superscriptsubscriptùê†ùëòùëõ‚àásubscriptùêπùëòsuperscriptùê∞ùëõ\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[\mathbf{g}_{k}^{(n)}]=\nabla F_{k}(\mathbf{w}^{(n)}),
(Bounded variance) ùîº‚Äã[‚Äñùê†k(n)‚àí‚àáFk‚Äã(ùê∞(n))‚Äñ2]‚â§Œ¥k2.ùîºdelimited-[]superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptùê†ùëòùëõ‚àásubscriptùêπùëòsuperscriptùê∞ùëõ2superscriptsubscriptùõøùëò2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[\|\mathbf{g}_{k}^{(n)}-\nabla F_{k}(\mathbf{w}^{(n)})\|^{2}]\leq\delta_{k}^{2}.

Assumptions 1 and 2 on local loss functions are standard, and they can be satisfied by many typical learning models, such as logistic regression, linear regression, and softmax classifier. Assumption 3 is general enough to cope with both i.i.d. and non-i.i.d. data distribution across edge devices, which follows the work in [33], [24], and [34]. Under Assumptions 1-3, the convergence rate of quantized FEEL is established in the following theorem.

Theorem 1.

Consider a quantized FEEL system with fixed quantization level q‚â•2ùëû2q\geq 2. The optimality gap of the loss function after NùëÅN communication rounds is upper bounded by

ùîº‚Äã[F‚Äã(ùê∞(N))]‚àíF‚Äã(ùê∞‚àó)ùîºdelimited-[]ùêπsuperscriptùê∞ùëÅùêπsubscriptùê∞‚àó\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[F(\mathbf{w}^{(N)})\right]-F(\mathbf{w}_{\ast})
‚â§Œ±‚ÄãŒ∫N+2‚ÄãŒ±‚ÄãŒ∫‚àí1‚Äã(L‚Äã‚Äñùê∞(0)‚àíùê∞‚àó‚Äñ2+2‚ÄãŒìŒº),absentùõºùúÖùëÅ2ùõºùúÖ1ùêøsuperscriptnormsuperscriptùê∞0subscriptùê∞‚àó22Œìùúá\displaystyle\leq\frac{\alpha\kappa}{N+2\alpha\kappa-1}\left(L\left\|\mathbf{w}^{(0)}-\mathbf{w}_{\ast}\right\|^{2}+\frac{2\Gamma}{\mu}\right),

where Œ±=dq‚ÄãK+1ùõºùëëùëûùêæ1\alpha=\frac{\sqrt{d}}{qK}+1, Œ∫=LŒºùúÖùêøùúá\kappa=\frac{L}{\mu}, FŒ¥=F‚Äã(ùê∞‚àó)‚àí1K‚Äã‚àëk=1KFk‚àósubscriptùêπùõøùêπsubscriptùê∞‚àó1ùêæsuperscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsuperscriptsubscriptùêπùëò‚àóF_{\delta}=F(\mathbf{w}_{\ast})-\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}F_{k}^{\ast} with Fk‚àó=minùê∞‚Å°Fk‚Äã(ùê∞)superscriptsubscriptùêπùëò‚àósubscriptùê∞subscriptùêπùëòùê∞F_{k}^{\ast}=\min\limits_{\mathbf{w}}F_{k}(\mathbf{w}), Œì=2‚ÄãL‚ÄãFŒ¥+1K‚Äã‚àëk=1KŒ¥k2Œì2ùêøsubscriptùêπùõø1ùêæsuperscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsuperscriptsubscriptùõøùëò2\Gamma=2LF_{\delta}+\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\delta_{k}^{2}, and ùê∞(0)superscriptùê∞0\mathbf{w}^{(0)} is the initial point of the training process. The learning rate is set to be a diminishing one, i.e., Œ∑n=2Œº‚Äã(n+2‚ÄãŒ±‚ÄãŒ∫‚àí1)subscriptùúÇùëõ2ùúáùëõ2ùõºùúÖ1\eta_{n}=\frac{2}{\mu(n+2\alpha\kappa-1)}.

Remark 1 (Convergence rate).

Theorem 1 quantizes the impact of gradient quantization on the convergence rate of the FEEL, which is captured by the term Œ±=dq‚ÄãK+1ùõºùëëùëûùêæ1\alpha=\frac{\sqrt{d}}{qK}+1. An aggressive quantization scheme, e.g., with small qùëûq, will lead to a enlarged optimality gap, and thus needs more rounds to converge. Nevertheless, the quantized FEEL can still achieve the asymptotic convergence rate of ùí™‚Äã(1N)ùí™1ùëÅ\mathcal{O}(\frac{1}{N}) as federated learning without quantization [33].

Remark 2 (Impact of data heterogeneity).

The term FŒ¥subscriptùêπùõøF_{\delta} measures the discrepancy between the minimum global loss and the average of the minimum local losses, which can be used for quantifying the heterogeneity level of data distribution among different devices [33]. As observed, if the data distribution is i.i.d., i.e., the data at different devices is sampled from a same distribution, then FŒ¥subscriptùêπùõøF_{\delta} goes to zero as the number of samples grows; otherwise, FŒ¥subscriptùêπùõøF_{\delta} is a non-zero constant depending on the skewness of data distribution. Therefore, Theorem 1 also offers quantitative insights on how data heterogeneity affects the convergence of quantized FEEL.

Although we can readily establish a bound on NœµsubscriptùëÅitalic-œµN_{\epsilon} based on Theorem 1 and apply this bound for subsequent resource optimization as did in prior work, e.g., [35] and [34], such an approach has two key drawbacks. Firstly, the gap between the derived bound and its true value could be large as several relaxations are made in deriving the bound. Thus, ignoring the gap may lead to highly suboptimal solution in the subsequent resource optimization. Secondly, even we adopt the upper bound and ignore the effects of the gap, it is still difficult to get the exact value of upper bound, since it involves calculating a bunch of data-related and model-related parameters, such as Œºùúá\mu, LùêøL, FŒ¥subscriptùêπùõøF_{\delta}, ùê∞‚àósubscriptùê∞‚àó\mathbf{w}_{\ast}, and ŒìŒì\Gamma.

To address the above issues, we propose a joint data-and-model-driven fitting approach, which uses a small amount of pre-training rounds to yield a good estimate of the optimality gap based on the bound derived in Theorem 1. To this end, we first denote the upper bound function derived in Theorem 1 as follows,

U^‚Äã(N)=Œ±‚ÄãŒ∫‚Äã(L‚Äã‚Äñùê∞0‚àíùê∞‚àó‚Äñ2+2‚ÄãŒìŒº)N+2‚ÄãŒ±‚ÄãŒ∫‚àí1.^ùëàùëÅùõºùúÖùêøsuperscriptnormsubscriptùê∞0subscriptùê∞‚àó22ŒìùúáùëÅ2ùõºùúÖ1\hat{U}(N)=\frac{\alpha\kappa\left(L\left\|\mathbf{w}_{0}-\mathbf{w}_{\ast}\right\|^{2}+\frac{2\Gamma}{\mu}\right)}{N+2\alpha\kappa-1}.

Before we derive the tight estimate of optimality gap, it is first observed that the upper bound function U^‚Äã(N)^ùëàùëÅ\hat{U}(N) satisfies the following properties:

  1. 1.

    U^‚Äã(N)^ùëàùëÅ\hat{U}(N) is a decreasing function of NùëÅN, and it converges to zero in a rate of ùí™‚Äã(1N)ùí™1ùëÅ\mathcal{O}(\frac{1}{N});

  2. 2.

    U^‚Äã(N)^ùëàùëÅ\hat{U}(N) has a fractional structure, where the numerator and denominator are both linear increasing functions of Œ±ùõº\alpha.

We assume that the ground-true optimality gap follows the same properties as its upper bound U^‚Äã(N)^ùëàùëÅ\hat{U}(N). Based on the above assumption, the exact optimality gap can be well estimated by the following function:

ùîº‚Äã[F‚Äã(ùê∞(N))]‚àíF‚Äã(ùê∞‚àó)=Œ±‚ÄãA+Dn+Œ±‚ÄãB+C‚âúU‚Äã(N),ùîºdelimited-[]ùêπsuperscriptùê∞ùëÅùêπsubscriptùê∞‚àóùõºùê¥ùê∑ùëõùõºùêµùê∂‚âúùëàùëÅ\mathbb{E}\left[F(\mathbf{w}^{(N)})\right]-F(\mathbf{w}_{\ast})=\frac{\alpha A+D}{n+\alpha B+C}\triangleq U(N), (8)

where A>0ùê¥0A>0, B>0ùêµ0B>0, C‚â•0ùê∂0C\geq 0, and D‚â•0ùê∑0D\geq 0 are tuning parameters to be fitted, which are implicitly related to the parameters, such as Œºùúá\mu, LùêøL, FŒ¥subscriptùêπùõøF_{\delta}, and ŒìŒì\Gamma. It can be seen that U‚Äã(N)ùëàùëÅU(N) generalizes all the functions that satisfy the two properties mentioned above.

Next, we apply a joint data-and-model-driven fitting method to fit the values of the tuning parameters as follows. Firstly, we randomly choose two quantization levels, say q1subscriptùëû1q_{1} and q2subscriptùëû2q_{2}, and run the quantized FEEL with q1subscriptùëû1q_{1} and q2subscriptùëû2q_{2}, respectively, from an initial model ùê∞0subscriptùê∞0\mathbf{w}_{0}. Then we sample the value of loss at each round until the number of communication rounds reaches a pre-defined value N~~ùëÅ\tilde{N}. The corresponding loss values are denoted as Fi,nsubscriptùêπùëñùëõF_{i,n} (i‚àà{1,2}ùëñ12i\in\{1,2\}, n‚àà[1,N~]ùëõ1~ùëÅn\in[1,\tilde{N}]) for round nùëõn when the quantization level is qisubscriptùëûùëñq_{i}. According to (8), we have that

Fi,n‚àíZ‚âàXin+Yi,‚àÄi‚àà{1,2},n‚àà[1,N~],formulae-sequencesubscriptùêπùëñùëõùëçsubscriptùëãùëñùëõsubscriptùëåùëñformulae-sequencefor-allùëñ12ùëõ1~ùëÅF_{i,n}-Z\approx\frac{X_{i}}{n+Y_{i}},\;\forall i\in\{1,2\},\;n\in[1,\tilde{N}], (9)

where Œ±i=dqi‚ÄãK+1subscriptùõºùëñùëësubscriptùëûùëñùêæ1\alpha_{i}=\frac{\sqrt{d}}{q_{i}K}+1, Z=F‚Äã(ùê∞‚àó)ùëçùêπsubscriptùê∞‚àóZ=F(\mathbf{w}_{\ast}), and

Xisubscriptùëãùëñ\displaystyle X_{i} =Œ±i‚ÄãA+D,absentsubscriptùõºùëñùê¥ùê∑\displaystyle=\alpha_{i}A+D, (10)
Yisubscriptùëåùëñ\displaystyle Y_{i} =Œ±i‚ÄãB+C.absentsubscriptùõºùëñùêµùê∂\displaystyle=\alpha_{i}B+C. (11)

Since the computations in (14) and (15) only involve limited algebraic operations, the computation time for solving the problem in (12) is negligible compared with the whole training process. With {Xi}subscriptùëãùëñ\{X_{i}\} and {Yi}subscriptùëåùëñ\{Y_{i}\} at hand, Aùê¥A, BùêµB, Cùê∂C, Dùê∑D can be obtained from (10) and (11) as following:

Based on the estimated optimality gap in (8) with the well-fitted parameters, we can derive NœµsubscriptùëÅitalic-œµN_{\epsilon} as in the following proposition.

Proposition 1.

In the quantized FEEL system, the minimum communication rounds to achieve œµitalic-œµ\epsilon-optimality gap is given by

Nœµ=‚åà(dq‚ÄãK+1)‚Äã(Aœµ‚àíB)+Dœµ‚àíC‚åâ.subscriptùëÅitalic-œµùëëùëûùêæ1ùê¥italic-œµùêµùê∑italic-œµùê∂N_{\epsilon}=\left\lceil\left(\frac{\sqrt{d}}{qK}+1\right)\left(\frac{A}{\epsilon}-B\right)+\frac{D}{\epsilon}-C\right\rceil. (16)
Proof.

By setting the fitted optimality gap in (8) less than œµitalic-œµ\epsilon, i.e., U‚Äã(N)‚â§œµùëàùëÅitalic-œµU(N)\leq\epsilon, and respecting the fact that the minimum communication rounds should be an integer, we obtain (16). ‚àé

Remark 3 (Impact of quantization level and device number).

Proposition 1 unveils the impact of quantization level and the number of participating devices on the minimum communication rounds as reflected by the term dq‚ÄãK+1ùëëùëûùêæ1\frac{\sqrt{d}}{qK}+1. On one hand, NœµsubscriptùëÅitalic-œµN_{\epsilon} decreases with increasing number of the quantization level qùëûq. This is due to the fact that increasing the quantization levels leads to less quantization error, which speeds up the convergence. On the other hand, we can observe that as the number of devices goes to infinity, i.e., K‚Üí‚àû‚ÜíùêæK\rightarrow\infty, the impact of quantization diminish since the quantization errors average out thanks to the update aggregation mechanism. Moreover, We can obtain that Nœµ=‚åàA+Dœµ‚àíB‚àíC‚åâsubscriptùëÅitalic-œµùê¥ùê∑italic-œµùêµùê∂N_{\epsilon}=\left\lceil\frac{A+D}{\epsilon}-B-C\right\rceil when q‚Üí‚àû‚Üíùëûq\rightarrow\infty or K‚Üí‚àû‚ÜíùêæK\rightarrow\infty. In other words, ‚åàA+Dœµ‚àíB‚àíC‚åâùê¥ùê∑italic-œµùêµùê∂\left\lceil\frac{A+D}{\epsilon}-B-C\right\rceil can be used to evaluate the minimum communication rounds under high-resolution quantization or sufficient large number of devices, and this value offers us a lower bound of the minimum communication rounds under practical quantization levels and number of devices.

IV Training time minimization

In this section, we aim to jointly optimize the quantization level and the bandwidth allocation by minimizing the training time defined in (5) to achieve an œµitalic-œµ\epsilon-optimality gap.

IV-A Problem formulation

The training time minimization problem is mathematically formulated by

(P1)‚Äãmin¬†q‚àà‚Ñ§+,{bk},TdP1ùëûsuperscript‚Ñ§subscriptùëèùëòsubscriptùëáùëëmin¬†\displaystyle(\text{P1})\;\;\;\underset{q\in\mathbb{Z}^{+},\{b_{k}\},T_{d}}{\text{min }}\;\;\; Td‚ãÖNœµ,‚ãÖsubscriptùëáùëësubscriptùëÅitalic-œµ\displaystyle T_{d}\cdot N_{\epsilon}, (17)
s.t. Tkcomp+Tkcomm‚â§Td,‚àÄk‚àà[K],formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptùëáùëòcompsuperscriptsubscriptùëáùëòcommsubscriptùëáùëëfor-allùëòdelimited-[]ùêæ\displaystyle T_{k}^{\text{comp}}+T_{k}^{\text{comm}}\leq T_{d},\;\forall k\in[K], (17a)
‚àëk=1Kbk=B0,superscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsubscriptùëèùëòsubscriptùêµ0\displaystyle\sum_{k=1}^{K}b_{k}=B_{0}, (17b)
q‚â•2,ùëû2\displaystyle q\geq 2, (17c)

where the objective function in (17) is the total training time needed to achieve œµitalic-œµ\epsilon-optimality gap. Constraints in (17a) indicate that the training time of each device per communication round cannot exceed the delay requirement TdsubscriptùëáùëëT_{d}. Equation (17b) constrains total bandwidth allocated to all the devices as BùêµB. The constraint on the quantization level qùëûq is described by (17c).

The objective function in (17) is complicated due to the coupling of the control variables TdsubscriptùëáùëëT_{d} and qùëûq. Moreover, qùëûq can only take values from positive integers. Therefore, Problem (P1) is non-convex, and challenging to be solved optimally. To yield a good solution to Problem (P1), we divide it into two sub-problems. One is finding the optimal bandwidth allocation {bk}subscriptùëèùëò\{b_{k}\} and TdsubscriptùëáùëëT_{d} with fixed quantization level qùëûq; the other is finding the optimal quantization level qùëûq with fixed bandwidth allocation {bk}subscriptùëèùëò\{b_{k}\} and TdsubscriptùëáùëëT_{d}. We will find that the first sub-problem can be solved optimally and efficiently with unique solution, and the second sub-problem can be transformed into a non-convex problem that can be solved by the method of successive convex approximation (SCA) [15]. Then, by alternatively solving each sub-problem, we can obtain good sub-optimal solutions to joint quantization level and bandwidth allocation optimization.

Remark 4 (Tradeoff between minimum communication rounds and per-round latency).

As noted in Remark 3, the minimum communication rounds NœµsubscriptùëÅitalic-œµN_{\epsilon} can be reduced by increasing the quantization levels qùëûq, but at a cost of increased per-round latency. Therefore, there exists a fundamental trade-off between reducing the minimum communication rounds and suppressing the per-round latency when minimizing the total training time. The trade-off is manipulated by the setting of quantization level qùëûq.

Remark 5 (Resource allocation over heterogeneous devices in FEEL).

The computation time of the devices varies due to their heterogeneous computation capacity. To enforce the per-round latency constraint, more frequency bandwidth should be allocated to the devices with low computation power so as to compensate the long computation time with short communication time, and vice versa. Hence, the bandwidth allocation among the devices should jointly account for the channel condition and also the computation resources, which is in sharp contrast to classic bandwidth allocation problem account for only the channel condition, e.g., in [36].

Since it holds that ‚àëk=1Kbk=B0superscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsubscriptùëèùëòsubscriptùêµ0\sum_{k=1}^{K}b_{k}=B_{0}, we can find TdsubscriptùëáùëëT_{d} by solving the equation as follows

‚àëk=1Kbk‚Äã(Td)=B0.superscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsubscriptùëèùëòsubscriptùëáùëësubscriptùêµ0\sum_{k=1}^{K}b_{k}(T_{d})=B_{0}. (21)

It can be verified that bk‚Äã(Td)subscriptùëèùëòsubscriptùëáùëëb_{k}(T_{d}) is a decreasing function of TdsubscriptùëáùëëT_{d}. Therefore, Equation (21) can be efficiently solved by bisection search. Note that although Rk‚Äã(‚ãÖ)subscriptùëÖùëò‚ãÖR_{k}(\cdot) is an increasing function with closed form expression, it is nontrivial to obtain a tractable expression of Rk‚àí1‚Äã(‚ãÖ)subscriptsuperscriptùëÖ1ùëò‚ãÖR^{-1}_{k}(\cdot), so we can not get bksubscriptùëèùëòb_{k} with given TdsubscriptùëáùëëT_{d} directly from (20). with the tool of bisection search. This is feasible due to the monotonicity of RksubscriptùëÖùëòR_{k}.

In consequence, Problem (P2) can be solved by two-layer bisection search as summarized in Algorithm 1. In the outer layer bisection, we search TdsubscriptùëáùëëT_{d} in the range of [Td‚àí,Td+]superscriptsubscriptùëáùëësuperscriptsubscriptùëáùëë[T_{d}^{-},T_{d}^{+}], where Td‚àí=maxk‚Å°{Tkcomp}superscriptsubscriptùëáùëësubscriptùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùëáùëòcompT_{d}^{-}=\max\limits_{k}\{T_{k}^{\text{comp}}\} and Td+=maxk‚Å°{Tkcomp+Rk‚Äã(B0/K)}superscriptsubscriptùëáùëësubscriptùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùëáùëòcompsubscriptùëÖùëòsubscriptùêµ0ùêæT_{d}^{+}=\max\limits_{k}\{T_{k}^{\text{comp}}+R_{k}(B_{0}/K)\}. The inner layer bisection in Step 5 is implemented in the range of [0,B0]0subscriptùêµ0[0,B_{0}]. Since only single variable bksubscriptùëèùëòb_{k} involves in each bisection, the process is straightforward, and thus we omit the detailed steps for simplicity.

IV-C Quantization level optimization

Next, we focus on optimizing the quantization level qùëûq under fixed bandwidth allocation. First, we relax the value of qùëûq from integer to real number in interval q‚àà[2,+‚àû)ùëû2q\in[2,+\infty). For the convenience of optimization, we approximate NœµsubscriptùëÅitalic-œµN_{\epsilon} in Proposition 1 as Nœµ‚âàdq‚ÄãK‚ÄãH1+H2subscriptùëÅitalic-œµùëëùëûùêæsubscriptùêª1subscriptùêª2N_{\epsilon}\approx\frac{\sqrt{d}}{qK}H_{1}+H_{2}, where H1=Aœµ‚àíBsubscriptùêª1ùê¥italic-œµùêµH_{1}=\frac{A}{\epsilon}-B and H2=A+Dœµ‚àíB‚àíCsubscriptùêª2ùê¥ùê∑italic-œµùêµùê∂H_{2}=\frac{A+D}{\epsilon}-B-C, by getting rid of the ceiling operation. Then, we introduce an intermediate variable T~~ùëá\tilde{T}, and Problem (P1) reduces to

(P3)‚Äãmin¬†q,T~(P3)ùëû~ùëámin¬†\displaystyle\text{(P3)}\;\;\;\underset{q,\tilde{T}}{\text{min }}\;\;\; T~,~ùëá\displaystyle\tilde{T}, (22)
s.t. (Tkcomp+Tkcomm)‚Äã(dq‚ÄãK‚ÄãH1+H2)‚â§T~,superscriptsubscriptùëáùëòcompsuperscriptsubscriptùëáùëòcommùëëùëûùêæsubscriptùêª1subscriptùêª2~ùëá\displaystyle\left(T_{k}^{\text{comp}}+T_{k}^{\text{comm}}\right)\left(\frac{\sqrt{d}}{qK}H_{1}+H_{2}\right)\leq\tilde{T}, (22a)
q‚â•2.ùëû2\displaystyle q\geq 2. (22b)

Problem (P3) is non-convex due to the non-convexity of constrains in (22a). To tackle this problem, the successive convex approximation (SCA) technique can be applied to obtain a stationary point [15]. An algorithm summarizing the above procedure is given by Algorithm 2. The key idea is that in each iteration, the original problem is approximated by a tractable convex one at a given local point as elaborated below. To start with, we substitute Tkcomm=(1+log2‚Å°(1+q))‚ÄãdRksuperscriptsubscriptùëáùëòcomm1subscript21ùëûùëësubscriptùëÖùëòT_{k}^{\text{comm}}=\frac{\left(1+\log_{2}(1+q)\right)d}{R_{k}} into (22a), and obtain

(Tkcomp+(1+log2‚Å°(1+q))‚ÄãdRk)‚Äã(dq‚ÄãK‚ÄãH1+H2)‚â§T~.superscriptsubscriptùëáùëòcomp1subscript21ùëûùëësubscriptùëÖùëòùëëùëûùêæsubscriptùêª1subscriptùêª2~ùëá\left(T_{k}^{\text{comp}}+\frac{\left(1+\log_{2}(1+q)\right)d}{R_{k}}\right)\left(\frac{\sqrt{d}}{qK}H_{1}+H_{2}\right)\leq\tilde{T}.

After taking the logarithm of both sides, and rearranging, it yields

It can be verified that Jk‚Äã(q)subscriptùêΩùëòùëûJ_{k}(q) is a concave function of qùëûq. Recall that any concave function is globally upper-bounded by its first-order Taylor expansion at any point. Therefore, with given local point q(r)superscriptùëûùëüq^{(r)}, we can establish an upper bound of Jk‚Äã(q)subscriptùêΩùëòùëûJ_{k}(q) as

where Jk‚Ä≤‚Äã(q(r))superscriptsubscriptùêΩùëò‚Ä≤superscriptùëûùëüJ_{k}^{\prime}(q^{(r)}) is the derivative of Jk‚Äã(q)subscriptùêΩùëòùëûJ_{k}(q) at q(r)superscriptùëûùëüq^{(r)}, i.e.,

Jk‚Ä≤‚Äã(q(r))=K‚ÄãH2q(r)‚ÄãK‚ÄãH2+H1‚ÄãdsuperscriptsubscriptùêΩùëò‚Ä≤superscriptùëûùëüùêæsubscriptùêª2superscriptùëûùëüùêæsubscriptùêª2subscriptùêª1ùëë\displaystyle J_{k}^{\prime}(q^{(r)})=\frac{KH_{2}}{q^{(r)}KH_{2}+H_{1}\sqrt{d}}

By replacing Jk‚Äã(q)subscriptùêΩùëòùëûJ_{k}(q) in (23) with its upper bound J^k‚Äã(q)subscript^ùêΩùëòùëû\hat{J}_{k}(q), with given local point q(r)superscriptùëûùëüq^{(r)} at rùëür-th iteration, the next point at (r+1)ùëü1(r+1)-th iteration can be obtained by solving the following problem

(P3.1)‚Äãq(r+1)=arg‚Å°minùëû‚ÄãT~,(P3.1)superscriptùëûùëü1ùëû~ùëá\displaystyle\text{(P3.1)}\;\;\;q^{(r+1)}=\underset{q}{\arg\min}\;\;\;\tilde{T}, (24)
s.t. J^k‚Äã(q)‚àíln‚Å°(q‚ÄãK)‚àíln‚Å°(T~)‚â§0,‚àÄk‚àà[K],formulae-sequencesubscript^ùêΩùëòùëûùëûùêæ~ùëá0for-allùëòdelimited-[]ùêæ\displaystyle\hat{J}_{k}(q)-\ln(qK)-\ln(\tilde{T})\leq 0,\;\forall k\in[K], (24a)
q‚â•2.ùëû2\displaystyle q\geq 2. (24b)

Since the left side of constraint (24a) are jointly convex with respect to qùëûq and T~~ùëá\tilde{T}, Problem (P3.1) is convex, which can be solved by standard convex optimization tools such as CVXPY [38]. After the iterations converge, e.g., the gap between T~(r)superscript~ùëáùëü\tilde{T}^{(r)} and T~(r+1)superscript~ùëáùëü1\tilde{T}^{(r+1)} is lower than a given threshold, Problem (P3) is deemed solved.

IV-D A joint optimization algorithm

Since the unique solution of Problem (P2) can be obtained by Algorithm 1 and a stationary point of Problem (P3) can be reached by Algorithm 2, the sub-optimal bandwidth allocation and quantization level can be jointly obtained by alternately solving Problem (P2) and (P3), which is summarized in Algorithm 3. It can be verified that the sub-optimal solution from Algorithm 3 is a stationary point of the original Problem (P1).

Note that solving Problem (P1) may lead to non-integer qùëûq, which needs further rounding technique to yield an integer qùëûq for practical implementation. One possible rounding technique is discussed as follows. We denote T‚Äã(q,{bk})ùëáùëûsubscriptùëèùëòT(q,\{b_{k}\}) as the total training time in Problem (P1) when qùëûq and {bk}subscriptùëèùëò\{b_{k}\} is substituted. After finding the optimized quantization level q^^ùëû\hat{q} and optimal bandwidth allocation {bk‚àó}superscriptsubscriptùëèùëò‚àó\{b_{k}^{\ast}\}, the final quantization level q‚àósuperscriptùëû‚àóq^{\ast} is obtained as

q‚àó=arg‚Å°minq‚àà{‚åàq^‚åâ‚àí1,‚åàq^‚åâ}‚Å°T‚Äã(q,{bk‚àó}).superscriptùëû‚àósubscriptùëû^ùëû1^ùëûùëáùëûsuperscriptsubscriptùëèùëò‚àóq^{\ast}=\arg\min_{q\in\{\lceil\hat{q}\rceil-1,\lceil\hat{q}\rceil\}}T(q,\{b_{k}^{\ast}\}).

V Experimental evaluation

In this section, we provide numerical results of two experiments under different wireless communication scenarios and learning tasks, which capture real system heterogeneity, to examine our theoretical results. In Experiment I, we consider a learning task with strongly convex loss function and training model of small size. In Experiment II, to stretch the theory, we consider a learning task with non-convex loss function and training model of large size. Although our analysis is developed based on the assumption of strongly convex loss function, we show that the proposed algorithm can also work well in the case with non-convex loss function. All experiments are implemented by PyTorch using Python 3.8 on a Linux server with one NVIDIA¬Æ GeForce¬Æ RTX 3090 GPU 24GB and one Intel¬Æ Xeon¬Æ Gold 5218 CPU.

V-A Experiment setup

FEEL system: We consider a FEEL system with a edge server covering a circular area of radius r=500ùëü500r=500 m. Within the area, K=6ùêæ6K=6 edge devices are placed randomly and distributed uniformly over the circular area with the exclusion of a central disk of radius rh=100subscriptùëü‚Ñé100r_{h}=100 m. The transmit power of each device is 111 dBm. To expose the heterogeneity of the edge devices, the CPU frequency of each device is assumed to be uniformly distributed from 100100100 MHz to 1 GHz. The number of processing cycles of device kùëòk for executing one batch of samples is ŒΩ=108ùúàsuperscript108\nu=10^{8} in Experiment I and ŒΩ=2.5√ó1010ùúà2.5superscript1010\nu=2.5\times 10^{10} in Experiment II.

Wireless propagation: The large-scale propagation coefficient in dB from device kùëòk to the edge server is modeled as [œïk]dB=[PLk]dB+[Œ∂k]dBsubscriptdelimited-[]subscriptitalic-œïùëòdBsubscriptdelimited-[]subscriptPLùëòdBsubscriptdelimited-[]subscriptùúÅùëòdB[\phi_{k}]_{\text{dB}}=[\text{PL}_{k}]_{\text{dB}}+[\zeta_{k}]_{\text{dB}}, where [PLk]dB=128.1+37.6‚Äãlog10‚Å°distksubscriptdelimited-[]subscriptPLùëòdB128.137.6subscript10subscriptdistùëò[\text{PL}_{k}]_{\text{dB}}=128.1+37.6\log_{10}\text{dist}_{k} (distksubscriptdistùëò\text{dist}_{k} is the distance in kilometer) is the path loss in dB, and [Œ∂k]dBsubscriptdelimited-[]subscriptùúÅùëòdB[\zeta_{k}]_{\text{dB}} is the shadow fading in dB [39]. In this simulation, [Œ∂k]dBsubscriptdelimited-[]subscriptùúÅùëòdB[\zeta_{k}]_{\text{dB}} is Gauss-distributed random variable with mean zero and variance œÉŒ∂2=8subscriptsuperscriptùúé2ùúÅ8\sigma^{2}_{\zeta}=8 dB. The noise power spectral density is N0=‚àí174subscriptùëÅ0174N_{0}=-174 dBm/Hz, and the total bandwidth is B0=10subscriptùêµ010B_{0}=10 KHz [28].

Learning tasks and models: In Experiment I, we consider the ‚Ñì2subscript‚Ñì2\ell_{2} regularized logistic regression task on synthetic data [40]. The local loss function in (1) at device kùëòk is given by

Therefore, we choose this dataset in Experiment I to better validate our theoretical results. We generate 48,000 data points for training and 12,000 data points for validation.

In Experiment II, we consider the learning task of image classification using the well-known CIFAR-10 dataset, which consists of 50,000 training images and 10,000 validation images in 10 categories of colorful objectives such as airplanes, cars, etc. ResNet-20 (269,722 parameters in total) with batch normalization444The implementation of ResNet-20 follows this GitHub repository: https://github.com/hclhkbu/GaussianK-SGD [41]. is applied as the classifier model [42].

To deliver rigorous results, we strictly control all unrelated variables in both experiments.

V-B Experiment results in Experiment I

V-B1 Estimation of data-related parameters

In the optimization in Section IV-C, we need to obtain the values of H1subscriptùêª1H_{1} and H2subscriptùêª2H_{2} using the proposed joint data-and-model-driven fitting method in Section III-C. With the joint data-and-model-driven fitting method, for any given two quantization levels q1subscriptùëû1q_{1} and q2subscriptùëû2q_{2}, and the threshold of loss optimality gap upper bound œµitalic-œµ\epsilon, we can obtain an estimation of H1subscriptùêª1H_{1} and H2subscriptùêª2H_{2}, which are used in Algorithm 3. Also, the optimal loss value can be obtained by the estimation of ZùëçZ in Eq. (9), i.e., F‚Äã(ùê∞‚àó)‚âàZ‚âà0.247ùêπsubscriptùê∞‚àóùëç0.247F(\mathbf{w}_{\ast})\approx Z\approx 0.247. The threshold of loss optimality gap upper bound is set as œµ=0.012italic-œµ0.012\epsilon=0.012. One can choose any combination of q1subscriptùëû1q_{1} and q2subscriptùëû2q_{2} to implement the estimation in theory. As a reminder to the readers, however, in our experience, the combination of q1subscriptùëû1q_{1} and q2subscriptùëû2q_{2} with large difference leads to better estimation accuracy. In our results, we choose (q1,q2)=(4,6)subscriptùëû1subscriptùëû246(q_{1},q_{2})=(4,6) in the joint data-and-model-driven fitting method, and obtain that H1‚âà43.01subscriptùêª143.01H_{1}\approx 43.01 and H2‚âà48.79subscriptùêª248.79H_{2}\approx 48.79. To show the robustness of our estimation method, we plot the fitted loss function and the actual loss when the quantization levels are q1=4subscriptùëû14q_{1}=4 and q2=6subscriptùëû26q_{2}=6, and also other values than q1subscriptùëû1q_{1} and q2subscriptùëû2q_{2}, e.g., 888 and 161616, as shown in Fig. 3, and we can see that the fitted loss function fits the actual loss well.

V-B2 Optimization of quantization level

Fig. 4 plots the total training time versus communication round in simulation when the bandwidth allocation is optimal. We run the same training process for at least 5 times on each quantization level. Fig. 4 shows that there exists optimal quantization level that minimizes the total training time. Recall the facts from Section III that the total training time T=Nœµ‚ãÖTdùëá‚ãÖsubscriptùëÅitalic-œµsubscriptùëáùëëT=N_{\epsilon}\cdot T_{d}, and NœµsubscriptùëÅitalic-œµN_{\epsilon} is an decreasing function of quantization level qùëûq, while TdsubscriptùëáùëëT_{d} is an increasing function of qùëûq. In other words, Fig. 4 demonstrates the trade-off between total communication rounds NœµsubscriptùëÅitalic-œµN_{\epsilon} and per-round latency TdsubscriptùëáùëëT_{d} in FEEL system. Moreover, it can be observed from the figure that the optimal quantization levels obtained in theory from Algorithm 3 in Section IV match the results by simulation, which confirms the validity of our proposed algorithms. In Fig. 5(a), we compare the training loss under optimal quantization level and optimal bandwidth allocation and the training loss under other quantization level and optimal bandwidth allocation. It can be observed that the training loss of optimal quantization level under optimal bandwidth allocation reaches the predefined threshold in a shorter time.

V-B3 Optimization of bandwidth

Fig. 5 depicts the comparison between the schemes with optimal and equal bandwidth allocation in terms of loss optimality gap and test accuracy. We can observe that the scheme with optimal bandwidth allocation can reach the predefined threshold and obtain a higher test accuracy in a shorter time. This indicates that our bandwidth allocation algorithm is effective and necessary in FEEL system. To show how the heterogeneous computation power of edge devices affect the communication resource allocation, we present the CPU frequency of each edge device and its corresponding optimal allocated bandwidth in Fig. 6. It can be observed that the edge devices with lower CPU frequency will be allocated with a larger bandwidth, which in spirit has similarity to the well-known phenomenon of ‚Äúwater-filling‚Äù in the problem of power allocation in wireless communication [36].

V-C Experiment results in Experiment II

We conduct Experiment II to evaluate our method and algorithms on learning model with non-convex loss function. In this experiment, we choose (q1,q2)=(15,20)subscriptùëû1subscriptùëû21520(q_{1},q_{2})=(15,20) and obtain H1‚âà96.26subscriptùêª196.26H_{1}\approx 96.26 and H2‚âà808.53subscriptùêª2808.53H_{2}\approx 808.53 by our joint data-and-model-driven fitting method. The threshold of loss optimality gap upper bound is set as œµ=0.22italic-œµ0.22\epsilon=0.22. Fig. 7 shows the total training time versus quantization level in simulation when the bandwidth allocation is optimal; Fig. 8 shows the loss value and test accuracy versus training time in simulation with different quantization levels and bandwidth allocations. We can obtain the similar observations from Fig. 7 and Fig. 8 as in Experiment I, which reveals that our method and algorithm also work well in non-convex setting, although they are derived under strongly-convex setting.

VI Conclusion

This paper have studied the training time minimization for quantized FEEL with optimized quantization level and bandwidth allocation. On the basis of the convergence analysis of quantized FEEL and our proposed joint-data-and-model-driven fitting method, we derived the closed-form expression of the total training time and characterizes the trade-off between the convergence speed and communication overhead, which is governed by the quantization level. Next, we minimized the total training time by optimizing the quantization level and bandwidth allocation, for which a high-quality near-optimal solutions are obtained by alternating optimization. The theoretical results developed can be used to guide the system optimization and contribute to the understanding of how wireless communication system can properly coordinate resources to accomplish learning tasks. This also opens several directions for further research. One direction is to implement device sampling in quantized FEEL, in which how the bandwidth is allocated to minimize the training time is completely a different story. The other direction is to consider error compensation in quantized FEEL to mitigate the effects of compression errors.

This gives

By the Œºùúá\mu-strongly convexity of Fk‚Äã(ùê∞)subscriptùêπùëòùê∞F_{k}(\mathbf{w}), it follows that

‚ü®ùê∞‚àó‚àíùê∞(n),ùê†k(n)‚ü©subscriptùê∞‚àósuperscriptùê∞ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùê†ùëòùëõ\displaystyle\left\langle\mathbf{w}_{\ast}-\mathbf{w}^{(n)},\mathbf{g}_{k}^{(n)}\right\rangle
‚â§\displaystyle\leq Fk‚Äã(ùê∞‚àó)‚àíFk‚Äã(ùê∞(n))‚àíŒº2‚Äã‚Äñùê∞(n)‚àíùê∞‚àó‚Äñ2.subscriptùêπùëòsubscriptùê∞‚àósubscriptùêπùëòsuperscriptùê∞ùëõùúá2superscriptnormsuperscriptùê∞ùëõsubscriptùê∞‚àó2\displaystyle F_{k}(\mathbf{w}_{\ast})-F_{k}(\mathbf{w}^{(n)})-\frac{\mu}{2}\left\|\mathbf{w}^{(n)}-\mathbf{w}_{\ast}\right\|^{2}.

Hence, B2subscriptùêµ2B_{2} can be bounded by

B2subscriptùêµ2\displaystyle B_{2} ‚â§2‚ÄãŒ∑nK‚Äã‚àëk=1K(Fk‚Äã(ùê∞‚àó)‚àíFk‚Äã(ùê∞(n)))absent2subscriptùúÇùëõùêæsuperscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsubscriptùêπùëòsubscriptùê∞‚àósubscriptùêπùëòsuperscriptùê∞ùëõ\displaystyle\leq 2\frac{\eta_{n}}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\left(F_{k}(\mathbf{w}_{\ast})-F_{k}(\mathbf{w}^{(n)})\right)
‚àíŒº‚ÄãŒ∑n‚Äã‚Äñùê∞(n)‚àíùê∞‚àó‚Äñ2.ùúásubscriptùúÇùëõsuperscriptnormsuperscriptùê∞ùëõsubscriptùê∞‚àó2\displaystyle-\mu\eta_{n}\left\|\mathbf{w}^{(n)}-\mathbf{w}_{\ast}\right\|^{2}.

B-B Bound of ‚Äñùêö2‚Äñ2subscriptnormsubscriptùêö22\left\|\mathbf{a}_{2}\right\|_{2}

Since ùê†k(n)superscriptsubscriptùê†ùëòùëõ\mathbf{g}_{k}^{(n)}‚Äôs are independent and ùîºùí¨‚Äã[‚Äñùí¨‚Äã(ùê†k(n))‚àíùê†k(n)‚Äñ]2‚â§dq‚Äã‚Äñùê†k(n)‚Äñ2subscriptùîºùí¨superscriptdelimited-[]normùí¨superscriptsubscriptùê†ùëòùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùê†ùëòùëõ2ùëëùëûsuperscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptùê†ùëòùëõ2\mathbb{E}_{\mathcal{Q}}\left[\left\|\mathcal{Q}(\mathbf{g}_{k}^{(n)})-\mathbf{g}_{k}^{(n)}\right\|\right]^{2}\leq\frac{\sqrt{d}}{q}\left\|\mathbf{g}_{k}^{(n)}\right\|^{2} holds, it follows that

ùîºùí¨‚Äã[‚Äñùêö2‚Äñ2]‚â§d‚ÄãŒ∑n2q‚ÄãK2‚Äã‚àëk=1K‚Äñùê†k(n)‚Äñ2.subscriptùîºùí¨delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscriptùêö22ùëësuperscriptsubscriptùúÇùëõ2ùëûsuperscriptùêæ2superscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsuperscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptùê†ùëòùëõ2\mathbb{E}_{\mathcal{Q}}[\left\|\mathbf{a}_{2}\right\|^{2}]\leq\frac{\sqrt{d}\eta_{n}^{2}}{qK^{2}}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\left\|\mathbf{g}_{k}^{(n)}\right\|^{2}.

B-C Bound of (25)

With these bounds at hand, taking expectation of (25) over the stochastic quantizer ùí¨ùí¨\mathcal{Q} and stochastic gradient at round nùëõn, we have that

ùîº‚Äã[‚Äñùê∞(n+1)‚àíùê∞‚àó‚Äñ2]ùîºdelimited-[]superscriptnormsuperscriptùê∞ùëõ1subscriptùê∞‚àó2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\mathbf{w}^{(n+1)}-\mathbf{w}_{\ast}\right\|^{2}\right]
‚â§(1‚àíŒº‚ÄãŒ∑n)‚Äã‚Äñùê∞(n)‚àíùê∞‚àó‚Äñ2absent1ùúásubscriptùúÇùëõsuperscriptnormsuperscriptùê∞ùëõsubscriptùê∞‚àó2\displaystyle\leq\left(1-\mu\eta_{n}\right)\left\|\mathbf{w}^{(n)}-\mathbf{w}_{\ast}\right\|^{2}
+2‚ÄãŒ∑nK‚Äã‚àëk=1K(Fk‚Äã(ùê∞‚àó)‚àíFk‚Äã(ùê∞(n)))2subscriptùúÇùëõùêæsuperscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsubscriptùêπùëòsubscriptùê∞‚àósubscriptùêπùëòsuperscriptùê∞ùëõ\displaystyle+2\frac{\eta_{n}}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\left(F_{k}(\mathbf{w}_{\ast})-F_{k}(\mathbf{w}^{(n)})\right)
+Œ±‚ÄãŒ∑n2K‚Äã‚àëk=1Kùîº‚Äã‚Äñùê†k(n)‚Äñ2.ùõºsuperscriptsubscriptùúÇùëõ2ùêæsuperscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæùîºsuperscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptùê†ùëòùëõ2\displaystyle+\frac{\alpha\eta_{n}^{2}}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\mathbb{E}\|\mathbf{g}_{k}^{(n)}\|^{2}. (26)

Recall that Œ±=dq‚ÄãK+1ùõºùëëùëûùêæ1\alpha=\frac{\sqrt{d}}{qK}+1. From Assumption 3, we have that

ùîº‚Äã‚Äñùê†k(n)‚Äñ2‚â§Œ¥k2+‚Äñ‚àáFk‚Äã(ùê∞(n))‚Äñ2.ùîºsuperscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptùê†ùëòùëõ2superscriptsubscriptùõøùëò2superscriptnorm‚àásubscriptùêπùëòsuperscriptùê∞ùëõ2\mathbb{E}\|\mathbf{g}_{k}^{(n)}\|^{2}\leq\delta_{k}^{2}+\|\nabla F_{k}(\mathbf{w}^{(n)})\|^{2}. (27)

After substituting (27) into (26), it yields

ùîº‚Äã[‚Äñùê∞(n+1)‚àíùê∞‚àó‚Äñ2]ùîºdelimited-[]superscriptnormsuperscriptùê∞ùëõ1subscriptùê∞‚àó2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\mathbf{w}^{(n+1)}-\mathbf{w}_{\ast}\right\|^{2}\right]
‚â§(1‚àíŒº‚ÄãŒ∑n)‚Äã‚Äñùê∞(n)‚àíùê∞‚àó‚Äñ2absent1ùúásubscriptùúÇùëõsuperscriptnormsuperscriptùê∞ùëõsubscriptùê∞‚àó2\displaystyle\leq\left(1-\mu\eta_{n}\right)\left\|\mathbf{w}^{(n)}-\mathbf{w}_{\ast}\right\|^{2}
+2‚ÄãŒ∑nK‚Äã‚àëk=1K(Fk‚Äã(ùê∞‚àó)‚àíFk‚Äã(ùê∞(n)))2subscriptùúÇùëõùêæsuperscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsubscriptùêπùëòsubscriptùê∞‚àósubscriptùêπùëòsuperscriptùê∞ùëõ\displaystyle+2\frac{\eta_{n}}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\left(F_{k}(\mathbf{w}_{\ast})-F_{k}(\mathbf{w}^{(n)})\right)
+Œ±‚ÄãŒ∑n2K‚Äã‚àëk=1K(Œ¥k2+‚Äñ‚àáFk‚Äã(ùê∞(n))‚Äñ2).ùõºsuperscriptsubscriptùúÇùëõ2ùêæsuperscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsuperscriptsubscriptùõøùëò2superscriptnorm‚àásubscriptùêπùëòsuperscriptùê∞ùëõ2\displaystyle+\frac{\alpha\eta_{n}^{2}}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\left(\delta_{k}^{2}+\|\nabla F_{k}(\mathbf{w}^{(n)})\|^{2}\right).

The LùêøL-smoothness of Fk‚Äã(ùê∞)subscriptùêπùëòùê∞F_{k}(\mathbf{w}) gives that

‚Äñ‚àáFk‚Äã(ùê∞(n))‚Äñ2‚â§2‚ÄãL‚Äã(Fk‚Äã(ùê∞(n))‚àíFk‚àó),superscriptnorm‚àásubscriptùêπùëòsuperscriptùê∞ùëõ22ùêøsubscriptùêπùëòsuperscriptùê∞ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùêπùëò‚àó\|\nabla F_{k}(\mathbf{w}^{(n)})\|^{2}\leq 2L\left(F_{k}(\mathbf{w}^{(n)})-F_{k}^{\ast}\right),

It follows that

ùîº‚Äã[‚Äñùê∞(n+1)‚àíùê∞‚àó‚Äñ2]ùîºdelimited-[]superscriptnormsuperscriptùê∞ùëõ1subscriptùê∞‚àó2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\mathbf{w}^{(n+1)}-\mathbf{w}_{\ast}\right\|^{2}\right]
‚â§(1‚àíŒº‚ÄãŒ∑n)‚Äã‚Äñùê∞(n)‚àíùê∞‚àó‚Äñ2+Œ±‚ÄãŒ∑n2K‚Äã‚àëk=1KŒ¥k2absent1ùúásubscriptùúÇùëõsuperscriptnormsuperscriptùê∞ùëõsubscriptùê∞‚àó2ùõºsuperscriptsubscriptùúÇùëõ2ùêæsuperscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsuperscriptsubscriptùõøùëò2\displaystyle\leq\left(1-\mu\eta_{n}\right)\left\|\mathbf{w}^{(n)}-\mathbf{w}_{\ast}\right\|^{2}+\frac{\alpha\eta_{n}^{2}}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\delta_{k}^{2}
+2‚ÄãŒ∑nK‚Äã‚àëk=1K(Fk‚Äã(ùê∞‚àó)‚àíFk‚Äã(ùê∞(n)))‚èüC1subscript‚èü2subscriptùúÇùëõùêæsuperscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsubscriptùêπùëòsubscriptùê∞‚àósubscriptùêπùëòsuperscriptùê∞ùëõsubscriptùê∂1\displaystyle+\underbrace{2\frac{\eta_{n}}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\left(F_{k}(\mathbf{w}_{\ast})-F_{k}(\mathbf{w}^{(n)})\right)}_{C_{1}}
+2‚ÄãL‚ÄãŒ∑n2‚ÄãŒ±K‚Äã‚àëk=1K(Fk‚Äã(ùê∞(n))‚àíFk‚àó)‚èüC2.subscript‚èü2ùêøsuperscriptsubscriptùúÇùëõ2ùõºùêæsuperscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsubscriptùêπùëòsuperscriptùê∞ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùêπùëò‚àósubscriptùê∂2\displaystyle+\underbrace{\frac{2L\eta_{n}^{2}\alpha}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\left(F_{k}(\mathbf{w}^{(n)})-F_{k}^{\ast}\right)}_{C_{2}}.

After rearranging C1+C2subscriptùê∂1subscriptùê∂2C_{1}+C_{2}, it becomes

+2‚ÄãŒ±‚ÄãL‚ÄãŒ∑n2‚ÄãFŒ¥,2ùõºùêøsuperscriptsubscriptùúÇùëõ2subscriptùêπùõø\displaystyle+2\alpha L\eta_{n}^{2}F_{\delta},

where FŒ¥‚âîF‚Äã(ùê∞‚àó)‚àí1K‚Äã‚àëk=1KFk‚àó‚âîsubscriptùêπùõøùêπsubscriptùê∞‚àó1ùêæsuperscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsuperscriptsubscriptùêπùëò‚àóF_{\delta}\coloneqq F(\mathbf{w}_{\ast})-\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}F_{k}^{\ast}. It can be verified that Œ∑n‚â§1Œ±‚ÄãLsubscriptùúÇùëõ1ùõºùêø\eta_{n}\leq\frac{1}{\alpha L}, and from F‚Äã(ùê∞(n))‚â•F‚Äã(ùê∞‚àó)ùêπsuperscriptùê∞ùëõùêπsubscriptùê∞‚àóF(\mathbf{w}^{(n)})\geq F(\mathbf{w}_{\ast}), we have

Taking total expectation of (25), it yields that

ùîº‚Äã[‚Äñùê∞(n+1)‚àíùê∞‚àó‚Äñ2]ùîºdelimited-[]superscriptnormsuperscriptùê∞ùëõ1subscriptùê∞‚àó2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\mathbf{w}^{(n+1)}-\mathbf{w}_{\ast}\right\|^{2}\right] ‚â§(1‚àíŒº‚ÄãŒ∑n)‚Äãùîº‚Äã[‚Äñùê∞(n)‚àíùê∞‚àó‚Äñ2]absent1ùúásubscriptùúÇùëõùîºdelimited-[]superscriptnormsuperscriptùê∞ùëõsubscriptùê∞‚àó2\displaystyle\leq\left(1-\mu\eta_{n}\right)\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\mathbf{w}^{(n)}-\mathbf{w}_{\ast}\right\|^{2}\right]
+Œ±‚ÄãŒ∑n2‚Äã(2‚ÄãL‚ÄãFŒ¥+1K‚Äã‚àëk=1KŒ¥k2),ùõºsuperscriptsubscriptùúÇùëõ22ùêøsubscriptùêπùõø1ùêæsuperscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsuperscriptsubscriptùõøùëò2\displaystyle+\alpha\eta_{n}^{2}(2LF_{\delta}+\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\delta_{k}^{2}),

which completes the proof.

Appendix C Proof of Lemma 1

If Tkcomp+Tkcomm<TdsuperscriptsubscriptùëáùëòcompsuperscriptsubscriptùëáùëòcommsubscriptùëáùëëT_{k}^{\text{comp}}+T_{k}^{\text{comm}}<T_{d}, ‚àÄk‚àà[K]for-allùëòdelimited-[]ùêæ\forall k\in[K], TdsubscriptùëáùëëT_{d} can be reduced until some k‚àà[K]ùëòdelimited-[]ùêæk\in[K] satisfy that Tkcomp+Tkcomm=TdsuperscriptsubscriptùëáùëòcompsuperscriptsubscriptùëáùëòcommsubscriptùëáùëëT_{k}^{\text{comp}}+T_{k}^{\text{comm}}=T_{d}. Since TkcommsuperscriptsubscriptùëáùëòcommT_{k}^{\text{comm}} is an decreasing function of bksubscriptùëèùëòb_{k}, we can enforce Tkcomp+Tkcomm=TdsuperscriptsubscriptùëáùëòcompsuperscriptsubscriptùëáùëòcommsubscriptùëáùëëT_{k}^{\text{comp}}+T_{k}^{\text{comm}}=T_{d} by decreasing bksubscriptùëèùëòb_{k} for all k‚ààùí¶ùëòùí¶k\in\mathcal{K}.
